snippet: A decision to uphold prison sentences for three of Sahar Gul’s in-laws is an exception to the prevailing treatment of women in Afghanistan.
abstract: Decision to uphold prison sentences for three of Sahar Gul’s in-laws is an exception to the prevailing treatment of women in Afghanistan; girl was tortured and thrown into a cellar, where police discovered her, for refusing to prostitute herself or have sex with the man she was forced to illegally marry at age 13; her case is a small victory that masks a still-depressing picture of widespread abuse of women.

byline.contributor: Jawad Sukhanyar contributed reporting from Kabul, and an employee of The New York Times from Baghlan Province, Afghanistan.

lead_paragraph: A decision to uphold prison sentences for three of Sahar Gul’s in-laws is an exception to the prevailing treatment of women in Afghanistan.

headline.main: Wed and Tortured at 13, Afghan Girl Finds Rare Justice
headline.print_headline: Wed and Tortured at 13, Afghan Girl Finds Rare Justice
